issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares RollerCoaster.numberOfLoopings as type int (problem_statement.md, lines 26-28), but the solution implementation declares numberOfLoopings as double and uses a constructor parameter of type double (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/RollerCoaster.java, lines 5-9). Additionally, LaunchedRollerCoaster in the solution declares its constructor parameter as int and passes it to the superclass constructor (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/LaunchedRollerCoaster.java, lines 5-7), causing a cross-artifact/type inconsistency. This mismatch between the UML/specification (int) and the solution implementation (double) can confuse students about the expected attribute and constructor parameter type and may cause tests or student implementations to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the types across artifacts. Preferably change the solution to match the UML/problem statement by making numberOfLoopings an int everywhere: declare private int numberOfLoopings in RollerCoaster, use a constructor parameter int numberOfLoopings and return int from the getter; ensure LaunchedRollerCoaster and any other subclasses use int for the parameter and pass it to super. Alternatively, if double was intended, update the UML/problem statement to specify double for numberOfLoopings and document this change.
